headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Bank Of America CEO: We Don't Understand What AI Can Do Yet; Rep. Mike Waltz (R-FL) On Donald Trump's Decisive Win Of The Iowa Republican Caucuses; Evangelicals Lift Trump To Dominant Victory In Iowa. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: RICHARD QUEST, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: And if you will, is going to do well.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BRIAN MOYNIHAN, CEO, BANK OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: Last year at this time when I was on with you, we had a recession predictor --

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MOYNIHAN
utterances.sentences: -- that kept pushing it out.Now, what's that attributed to in the U.S. particularly? It's attributable to the U.S. consumer. We have people who are making money and are employed. Unemployment is very low. They're getting paid more. Inflation is still tough on a lot of them so you can't discount that. But on the other hand, the stock market being up. On the other hand, they've accumulated wealth. On the other hand, they're making more -- a lot more money. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: The totality of what he's been talking about is so much more optimistic than anything we've seen elsewhere from other people.And the big issue, of course, is AI, artificial intelligence. Everybody -- there is an orgy of AI going up on the promenade at the moment. Everybody's talking AI this, AI that. And so I asked Brian Moynihan what is it about AI and how is BOA doing AI? (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: But where do you think we are between that?

utterances.speaker: MOYNIHAN
utterances.sentences: I think we're here because it has such unusual promise.

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: MOYNIHAN
utterances.sentences: And so, unprepared, not in a negative sense, that we don't understand what it can do yet.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: And so, there you have it -- ready for AI, which is the core question that we're asking -- that we asked Brian. And you can see by now we've got lots of answers or getting more and more. The president of the European Commission, the Bank of America CEO, the head of NATO, Jens Stoltenberg.And you've always got to be careful with this thing that people don't gravitate too much in the middle. Well, now, they're gravitating that we are, as a society, dangerously unprepared. And I will allow both you and your good colleagues, where would you go on this, Poppy and Phil? Where would you go? So you can direct me left or right from this point.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: You first.

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I just -- I'll answer your question. Did you bring that on the plane with you or how did you -- the whiteboard. Is that -- like, how did you have that with you?

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: Secrets, secrets.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I knew it. I knew it. I can never get anything past you.So I'm leaning towards your left, Richard -- further towards your left.

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: So, OK -- all right. Shout stop.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Closer to the dangerously unprepared. You may -- a little bit closer. We'll go right there. Right there. Right there. That's great. No, you're still going.

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: OK. Poppy?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I'm further -- I'm further to the left. I'd be beyond Phil, beyond Brian Moynihan. I'm thinking about that warning we got yesterday from the IMF, Richard, about how many jobs are going to be dramatically changed because of AI.

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But at the same time, I'm really optimistic about what it could do in the right hands, handled the right way. So I miss you and your whiteboard and the mountains in Davos, Richard Quest. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: I'm putting you there.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Perfect. Thank you. MATTINGLY

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Fascinating and fun, as he always is.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I love his random whiteboard.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Of course he does.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Of course he does.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We are going to dig deeper into yesterday's results in Iowa. We're going to zero in on where the candidates did well and what this could mean for New Hampshire coming up.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: It was, at least for a moment, a striking conciliatory tone from the former president calling for unity after a decisive victory in Iowa last night.Meanwhile, Ron DeSantis barely eked out a second-place finish ahead of Nikki Haley, even after he poured a huge amount of resources into Iowa. Joining us now, Republican congressman from Florida, Mike Waltz. He has endorsed Donald Trump for president. Congressman, I appreciate your time this morning. Do you think at this point that every other Republican who is in the race should get out? REP. MIKE WALTZ (R-FL):  Well, it was certainly a historic, decisive victory. And I've got to tell you it was cold. And the caucus site where I spoke -- still, the organizers were telling me that they were surprised at how many people came out. Look, I think it is crystal clear President Trump is going to be the nominee. The sooner we get to that realization in the other campaigns the better. And then we can start drawing those contrasts with what the economy looked like under President Trump with how it is now. What the border looked like then and how it now. What the world situation with the world on fire right now. Just a few years ago, we've gone from Abraham Accords and Middle East Peace to multiple wars across the Middle East and in Europe. So, yeah, we're ready to get to that contrast sooner than later.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Nikki Haley, who made New Hampshire, which is next up, the centerpiece for her campaign putting out a new ad this morning and also having messaged last night saying look, nobody wants a rematch. If you look at the polls, most Americans don't want to see a replay of 2020.What do you say to that?

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: Well, I've got to say the Republican Party has made it clear and I think is going to continue to make it clear that President Trump is the leader of the party and that we want to get back to his policies that worked and that were working for the country and, frankly, were working for the world.And I think the premise that his opponents have been testing is you liked a lot of the America First policies, whether it was record low unemployment, inflation down, the border under control, crime on decline, the pivot on China, but can you get all of that without him? And I've argued that you don't get SpaceX without Elon Musk. You don't get Apple without Steve Jobs. And you don't get those policies that many leaders in the Republican Party say we want to emulate, get back to, and build on without the guy who had the vision and actually executed and put them in place.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: No. The numbers were very clear, at least in the state of Iowa.The downside risk, though, that you've heard some candidates lay out -- Ron DeSantis, in particular -- is that he also could be convicted over the course of -- with the 91 criminal charges that he faces. If the former president is convicted will you support him no matter what?

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: Look, with what we've seen getting laid out with this bogus, ridiculous case in New York, with what we're seeing now with the total conflict of interest and possibly corruption in Georgia, we could go down the list. These cases -- people see right through them. This is a weaponization of our Justice Department and it only bolstered support for President Trump. His numbers have only increased.So not only would I support him, I think you're going to see the American people support him.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: You mentioned the Fulton County D.A. case and also the New York case. You didn't mention the special counsel's case, both Jack Smith, including election interference and the classified documents.Do you think those are in that same lane?

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah. I mean, look, when we're starting to parse between legal theories, between the -- between the Espionage Act, between the Presidential Records Act -- when you have over 80 cases, according to the National Archives, of senators, members of Congress, and every presidential office and officeholder in the last several decades have had instances where they had disputes with classified documents. Where they sent them back and forth.Look, that -- I think the American people see all that. Are we really going to take the leader of a party -- of an opposition party off the ballot and out of action when he's been voted in -- when the American people clearly want him back in -- over these kind of -- over these kind of disputes? Look, that is -- that is, in my view, scary for our democracy when you have the party in power and its Justice Department going after its chief political opponent. I've served in places as a Green Beret around the world where that happens.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: I never expected to see it here.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I would also note that as -- given your service and when you had served, if you'd taken documents and put them in a bathroom in a large box that were considered top secret, you would also probably be in trouble.Can I ask you, though, before I let you go --

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: Fair enough but I wasn't the President of the United States.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: No, no, no -- I understand.

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: I governed by a lot of -- a lot of case law.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I understand on that one.

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: I don't think that's a -- I don't think that's quite the same analogy.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, I --

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: And fair that if we want to go down that road we can talk about boxes sitting in a garage, admittedly, completely unguarded. We can talk about as a member of Congress -- MATTINGLY

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: -- they take every document --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And look --

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: -- when you walk out of a SCIF.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I actually think this is a --

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: And then you have a -- years and years. How did they get there? On Amtrak? I mean --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I think there's

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: -- I think there's a lot to look into --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: -- (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Look, I understand and I would say, Congressman --

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: -- in the part of the Justice Department.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- I'm being entirely fair when I say this that there is a special counsel looking into that case as well -- Robert Hur, who has been assigned there. And I think there has not been an outcome yet that's announced. We certainly will cover it when it is announced.I think the analog in terms of the types of classified documents that were contained and where they were contained -- I don't know if there's a lot of precedent for that. But to your point, it is a president and we're going to have to wait and see how that case moves forward. Before I do let you go, though, on the political side of things. Almost the entire Republican delegation --

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- got behind the former president. Ron DeSantis is the governor of Florida and had a huge reelection victory.What is your message to him right now, in particular, given the fact that he's still in this race heading into New Hampshire?

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: I'll get to that. I just want to say one more thing with these cases though and I think this is a critical point. I didn't hear about that anywhere in Iowa. I don't hear about it back home in Florida. What I hear about are kitchen table issues and what President Trump --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: -- has done in his past. A vision going forward. He's not looking back in the past. So we're just not hearing that at all from anybody I'm talking to.In terms -- look, Gov. DeSantis has been a fantastic governor. I don't think we would have gotten through COVID the way Florida did --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: -- without his leadership.What I'm hearing from folks on the ground is they just don't understand why he didn't wait. He's a young guy with -- that's very bright. It's going to be an open presidential seat in '28 and a lot of people are shaking their heads. He's still got a lot of great work to do as governor and we look forward to seeing that.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: All right, Congressman Mike Waltz. Always appreciate your time, sir. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WALTZ
utterances.sentences: All right. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And today at noon on "INSIDE POLITICS" be sure to watch Dana Bash's sit-down interview with Nikki Haley and New Hampshire Gov. Chris Sununu.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Um-hum.

utterances.speaker: ALBERTA
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump is the lesser of two evils. We have to -- we have to hold our nose and vote for this guy to keep Hillary Clinton out of the White House.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But --

utterances.speaker: ALBERTA
utterances.sentences: Well, that seems like a lifetime ago because obviously, what we saw in Iowa last night was not a lesser of two evils situation. It was not a binary choice situation. Donald Trump winning 53 percent of all evangelical voters is just -- I mean, it's stunning, Poppy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: ALBERTA
utterances.sentences: And I think it does speak to -- it speaks to the evolution in this relationship from the lesser of two evils to really being a champion of a movement.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: For sure.Tim, listen to this from yesterday. We had Pastor Decker on. He is a pastor in Ottumwa, Iowa. And here is how he explained his support for Trump. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PASTOR TRAVIS DECKER, OTTUMWA BAPTIST TEMPLE
utterances.sentences: None of these candidates could be a Sunday School teacher in my church. So they're not on the same page. And I don't hold any of them as a specific role model for our family or our congregation. And none of them meet that bar, to me, biblically.I would love to see him become and grow more of a conscience in a lot of areas. But I think he has a proven track record --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: DECKER
utterances.sentences: -- of being a good president, especially on abortion.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That pastor and many evangelicals know exactly who Trump is and they wouldn't want him teaching Sunday School to their kids, but still 100 percent behind him.

utterances.speaker: ALBERTA
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Well -- and listen, I guess that's a more defensible position -- intellectually honest position than you hear from some other evangelical leaders who will tell you that they believe that Trump is actually -- has become born again himself and that he's actually an agent of the almighty and that he's really in his personal private life quite pious.I mean, you do have I think a large number of these voters, Poppy, who would say exactly what that pastor just said a moment ago, which is that they've made sort of a cold, calculating, political decision here --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Um-hum.

utterances.speaker: ALBERTA
utterances.sentences: -- that they believe that on a policy basis, he is able to deliver for them and has a track record that no other Republican candidate can match up to.What they're not necessarily willing or able to answer is the -- is this basic question of does someone's values -- someone like Donald Trump -- his values in talking about humans made in the image of God. Talking about them as vermin or talking about immigrants poisoning the blood of our nation. Someone who traffics in violent and often xenophobic and racist rhetoric. Does that person's -- just their core values -- does it align with some of your basic --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Um-hum.

utterances.speaker: ALBERTA
utterances.sentences: -- practicing beliefs --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And --

utterances.speaker: ALBERTA
utterances.sentences: -- as a follower of Jesus Christ aside from any policy --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: ALBERTA
utterances.sentences: -- proposals that he may adhere to.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And, Tim, for people who haven't read your book and all your reporting on evangelicals, you're also the son of an evangelical pastor. So you are steeped in this.I want to ask you about Nikki Haley before we go. You wrote, sort of, the profile on her in 2021. The title was "Nikki Haley's Time for Choosing." And in it, you said, "She doesn't know which Nikki Haley is going to be on the ballot." Do we know which Nikki Haley is on the ballot now? Because just last night she started grouping Trump and Biden together after refusing to go after Biden up until -- after Trump up until now. Who is the Nikki Haley now?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: ALBERTA
utterances.sentences: -- a chance to be his vice president or not. But it's just been sort of a shell of a campaign in many ways.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I'd urge people to go back -- because you spent months with her reporting that out -- to read it. And I'm sure she'll address this with Dana Bash today in their interview at noon Eastern time.Tim, thanks very much for joining us this morning.

utterances.speaker: ALBERTA
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Poppy.
